item.content:encoded: This is what should be on every front page right now. What's happening in the US right now is an illegal power grab by a private citizen. IT'S A COUP. It's a digital coup. It's Musk who's leading it. The consequences are terrifying. And it's coming for us next. 1/

item.content:encoded: POLITICO: As USAID retreats, China pounces ‚Äî ‚Ä¢ In Nepal, Beijing is signaling it's willing to step in to replace the void ‚Ä¢ In the Cook Islands, warnings that the vacuum will give an opening for China ‚Ä¢ In Colombia, China is already interested in filling the NGO gap

item.content:encoded: I can‚Äôt believe it - after years of advocacy, exclusionary zoning has ended in Cambridge. We just passed the single most comprehensive rezoning in the US‚Äîlegalizing multifamily housing up to 6 stories citywide in a Paris style Here‚Äôs the details üßµ

item.content:encoded: Surprisingly, ignoring worries can improve mental health. Evidence: After practice blocking out fears, people were less anxious‚Äîand less depressed 3 months later‚Äîespecially if they had high anxiety or PTSD. Not all concerns demand attention. Some thoughts are worth dismissing.

item.content:encoded: Franchisees are much better operators than McDonalds. While systemwide US sales fell 1%, company owned units fell 5%. As a result, company owned restaurant profit (now tiny part of $MCD) fell 33%. Why the great franchise-out made so much sense.

item.content:encoded: Two decades ago Germans invested in solar panels manufacturing in China, local partners learned from them how to build them and flooded the world, getting German manufacturers out of business. Similar thing is happening with cars now. It‚Äôs just starting, buckle up folks.

item.content:encoded: $250/mo gyms are not about nicer equipment. The point of a $250 gym membership is to exercise exclusively around other people able and willing to also pay $250/mo. They aren't expensive because they're desirable, they're desirable because they're expensive
